1: I'm a very popular pet that lives in people's homes.
I love to play fetch and go for walks with my owner.
I wag my tail when I'm happy and I say 'woof woof'!
2: I'm a small furry pet that many families love.
I like to nap in sunny spots and chase little toys.
I purr when I'm happy and I say 'meow'!
3: I'm a bird that lives on farms.
I peck at seeds on the ground and have a red comb on my head.
I lay eggs and wake everyone up in the morning with my crowing!
4: I spend my days grazing in green pastures.
I give milk and I say 'moo'!
5: I'm a farm animal known for my soft coat.
Farmers shear my fluffy wool once a year.
I say 'baa baa' and my wool is used to make sweaters!
6: I'm a farm animal that loves to eat.
I have a curly tail and a flat snout.
I love rolling in mud and I say 'oink oink'!
7: I'm a large animal that has been helping humans for thousands of years.
People ride on my back and I can run very fast.
I gallop through fields, have a flowing mane, and I say 'neigh'!
8: I'm a farm animal that lives on hillsides.
I have a beard and I love to climb on rocks.
I have horns and I say 'maa'!
9: I'm a strong animal related to the horse.
I have long ears and I'm known for being very stubborn.
I carry heavy loads and I say 'hee-haw'!
10: I'm a large bird that lives on farms.
I have a fan-shaped tail and a red wattle under my chin.
I'm the star of Thanksgiving dinner and I say 'gobble gobble'!
11: I'm a small, soft animal that can be a pet.
I have very long ears and I love munching on carrots.
I hop around and my nose wiggles all the time!
12: I'm a bird that lives near water.
I have webbed feet that help me swim.
I waddle when I walk and I say 'quack quack'!
13: I'm a farm bird that's bigger than a duck.
I have a long neck and I can be a very good guard animal.
I honk loudly and I sometimes chase people away!
14: I'm a tall animal from South America.
I have a long neck, soft fur, and I'm related to camels.
I'm known for spitting when I'm annoyed!
15: I come from the mountains of South America.
I look like a smaller, fluffier version of a llama.
My super soft wool is used to make the coziest sweaters!
16: I'm a small, cuddly pet that's not actually from a farm.
I make adorable squeaking sounds when I'm happy.
Despite my name, I'm not a pig at all -- I'm a rodent from South America!
17: I'm a tiny pet that lives in a cage.
I love running on my exercise wheel at night.
I store food in my big, puffy cheek pouches!
18: I'm a pet that lives in water.
I swim around in a bowl or a tank all day.
I'm a shiny orange fish that's often won as a prize at fairs!
19: I'm a small, colorful bird kept as a pet.
I can learn to repeat words and sounds people make.
I'm also called a budgie, and I come in green, blue, and yellow!
20: I'm a reptile that moves very slowly.
I carry my home on my back wherever I go.
I can pull my head and legs inside my hard shell for protection!
21: I'm a small, furry animal you can see in parks and backyards.
I have a big, bushy tail and I love climbing trees.
I collect and bury acorns and nuts to eat later!
22: I'm a small songbird you might spot in your garden.
I'm one of the first birds to sing in the morning.
I have a bright red-orange breast that makes me easy to recognize!
23: I'm a graceful animal that lives in forests.
I have long legs and I'm very good at jumping over fences.
The males grow beautiful antlers that fall off every year!
24: I'm a clever wild animal with a bushy tail.
I come out mostly at night and I'm known for being very sneaky.
I have red-orange fur and a white-tipped tail!
25: I'm a clever animal that comes out at night.
I wash my food in water before eating it.
I have a black mask across my eyes like a little bandit!
26: I'm a small animal that comes out at night.
I eat insects and snails in gardens.
I'm covered in sharp spines and I curl into a ball for protection!
27: I'm a small animal that lives near ponds and lakes.
I start my life as a tadpole swimming in water.
I hop around on long back legs and say 'ribbit ribbit'!
28: I'm a flying insect with a very special life cycle.
I start life as a caterpillar before I transform.
I have large, colorful wings with beautiful patterns!
29: I'm a tiny insect that gardeners love to see.
I'm considered to be very lucky in many countries.
I'm red with black spots and I eat pesky aphids!
30: I'm a small flying insect that lives in a big colony.
I visit flowers all day to collect something sweet.
I make honey and I live in a hive with my queen!
31: I'm a very slow creature you find in gardens.
I leave a slimy trail wherever I go.
I carry a spiral shell on my back and hide inside when scared!
32: I'm a bird that lives in cities all around the world.
I bob my head when I walk and I eat breadcrumbs in parks.
I coo softly and people sometimes call me a 'city dove'!
33: I'm a small, brown bird seen almost everywhere.
I hop along the ground looking for seeds and crumbs.
I'm one of the most common birds in the world and I chirp a lot!
34: I'm a flying animal but I'm not a bird.
I hang upside down to sleep during the day.
I use sound echoes to find my way in the dark!
35: I'm a very small animal that sneaks into houses.
I have large round ears and a thin, long tail.
I love cheese and I say 'squeak squeak'!
36: I'm a small mammal that lives underground.
I dig tunnels with my big, powerful front paws.
I'm nearly blind and I push up little hills of dirt in your yard!
37: I'm a flying insect found near ponds and streams.
I have two pairs of wings and I can fly in any direction.
I have a long, thin body and huge eyes, and I catch bugs mid-flight!
38: I'm a small, furry animal that lives in forests.
I have puffy cheeks and I love gathering nuts.
I have brown fur with black and white stripes on my back!
39: I'm a bird that hunts at night.
I can turn my head almost all the way around.
I have huge eyes, I'm very wise, and I say 'hoo hoo'!
40: I'm a bird that lives in forests.
I have a very strong beak that I use to find food.
I peck holes in tree trunks to find insects, and you can hear me drumming from far away!
41: I'm one of the smartest animals in the ocean.
I jump out of the water playfully and I communicate with clicks and whistles!
42: I'm the biggest creature in the ocean.
I breathe air even though I live in water.
I spray water from a blowhole on top of my head and I sing long, beautiful songs!
43: I'm a powerful predator that lives in the ocean.
I have rows and rows of sharp teeth that keep growing back.
I have a pointed dorsal fin that sticks out of the water!
44: I'm a sea creature with no bones at all.
I'm super smart and can solve puzzles and open jars.
I have eight arms with suction cups and I can squirt ink!
45: I'm a tiny ocean creature with an unusual shape.
I swim upright and I'm not a very fast swimmer.
My head looks like a tiny horse and the dad carries the babies!
46: I'm a sea creature that drifts through the ocean.
I don't have a brain, heart, or bones.
I have a see-through, squishy body with long stinging tentacles!
47: I'm a large reptile that lives in the ocean.
I travel thousands of miles to lay my eggs on sandy beaches.
I have flippers instead of legs and a big, beautiful shell!
48: I'm a small, colorful fish that lives in warm oceans.
I make my home among the stinging tentacles of an anemone.
I'm orange with white stripes, and I was the star of a famous movie about being found!
49: I'm a sea creature that lives on the ocean floor.
I can have five or more arms and I don't have a brain.
I'm shaped like a star and I can regrow my arms if I lose one!
50: I'm a sea creature with a hard outer body.
I walk sideways along the beach and ocean floor.
I have two big pinching claws and ten legs!
51: I'm a sea creature with a hard shell.
I live on the ocean floor and I can live for over 100 years.
I have two large claws and I turn bright red when cooked!
52: I'm a marine mammal that loves cold water.
I'm very playful and I can balance a ball on my nose.
I have smooth skin, flippers, and I bark like a dog!
53: I'm a very large marine mammal from the Arctic.
I have thick, wrinkly skin and lots of blubber to stay warm.
I have two long ivory tusks and big whiskers!
54: I'm a bird that cannot fly.
I live in very cold places and I love to swim.
I waddle on ice, have a black and white tuxedo look, and I slide on my belly!
55: I'm a fish with a very unusual defense.
When scared, I can make myself much bigger.
I puff up into a spiky ball and some parts of me are very poisonous!
56: I'm a very large, flat sea creature.
I glide gracefully through the water like I'm flying.
I have huge wing-like fins and a long, thin tail!
57: I'm a long, slippery fish that lives in the ocean.
I hide in crevices and come out at night to hunt.
I look like an underwater snake and some of my relatives can make electricity!
58: I'm a sea creature related to the octopus.
I have a long, torpedo-shaped body built for speed.
I have ten arms, big eyes, and I can squirt ink to escape predators!
59: I'm a large, powerful ocean predator.
I'm actually a member of the dolphin family, not a whale.
I'm black and white and I'm called the 'killer whale'!
60: I'm a mysterious sea creature from the Arctic.
I have a unique feature growing from my head.
I'm called the 'unicorn of the sea' because of my long spiral tusk!
61: I'm a big wild cat that lives in Africa.
I live in a group called a pride.
I have a big, fluffy mane and I'm called the 'King of the Jungle'!
62: I'm a large wild cat from Asia.
I love swimming, unlike most cats.
I have beautiful orange fur with black stripes!
63: I'm the largest animal that walks on land.
I use my long nose to grab food and spray water.
I have huge floppy ears, ivory tusks, and I never forget!
64: I'm the tallest animal on Earth.
I live in the African savanna and I eat leaves from treetops.
I have a super long neck and spotted brown patches on my body!
65: I'm a playful animal that lives in trees in warm places.
I love swinging from branch to branch using my hands and tail.
I eat bananas and I'm known for being very clever and silly!
66: I'm one of the strongest animals in the jungle.
I'm a great ape and I'm closely related to humans.
I have huge muscles, dark fur, and I beat my chest to show strength!
67: I have a curved beak and I'm very good at talking.
I can copy human words and I love crackers! Polly wants one!
68: I'm a tropical bird from Central and South America.
I have very bright, colorful feathers.
I have a huge, colorful beak that's almost as big as my body!
69: I'm a powerful wild cat from the Americas.
I love water and I'm an excellent swimmer.
I have a golden coat covered with dark rosette-shaped spots!
70: I slither along the ground and flick my forked tongue.
I hiss and some of my relatives can be venomous!
71: I'm a large reptile that lives in rivers and swamps.
I have a long snout and powerful jaws full of teeth.
I hide in the water with just my eyes showing, and I snap! See you later!
72: I'm one of the heaviest animals in Africa.
I spend most of my day in rivers and lakes to stay cool.
I have a huge mouth that opens super wide and stubby little legs!
73: I'm a massive animal with very tough, thick skin.
I live in Africa and Asia and I'm a herbivore.
I have one or two horns on my nose!
74: I'm a horse-like animal from the African savanna.
No two of us look exactly the same.
I'm white with black stripes -- or am I black with white stripes?
75: I'm a tropical reptile known for a very special ability.
I have eyes that can look in two different directions at once.
I can change the color of my skin to blend in with my surroundings!
76: I'm one of the slowest animals in the world.
I spend most of my life hanging upside down in trees.
I move so slowly that algae grows on my fur!
77: I'm a great ape that lives in the rainforests of Asia.
I have very long arms for swinging through the trees.
I have shaggy reddish-orange hair and my name means 'person of the forest'!
78: I'm a powerful big cat that roams tropical forests.
I hunt at night and I'm very hard to spot in the dark.
I'm actually a leopard or jaguar with all-black fur!
79: I'm a tall bird that lives near lakes and lagoons.
I stand on one leg a lot and I live in big flocks.
I'm bright pink because of the shrimp I eat!
80: I'm a large, fancy bird from Asia.
The males of my species put on quite a show.
I spread my enormous tail feathers into a fan of shimmering blue and green eyespots!
81: I'm a massive animal that lives in the coldest places on Earth.
I'm an excellent swimmer in freezing Arctic waters.
I have thick white fur and huge paws, and I'm the largest land carnivore!
82: I'm a small wild animal from the Arctic.
My fur changes color with the seasons.
I'm white in winter and brown in summer, and I have a fluffy tail and small rounded ears!
83: I'm a bird of prey from the Arctic.
Unlike most of my relatives, I often hunt during the day.
I have bright white feathers with dark markings, and I starred in a famous wizard movie!
84: I'm a large animal that lives in hot, dry deserts.
I can go a very long time without drinking water.
I have one or two humps on my back that store fat for energy!
85: I'm a small creature that lives in deserts and warm places.
I have eight legs and two large pincers.
I have a curved, stinging tail that I hold over my back!
86: I'm a reptile that lives in dry, rocky deserts.
I have a pattern of diamond shapes along my body.
I shake the tip of my tail to make a buzzing warning sound!
87: I'm a small animal from the deserts of Africa.
I live in large groups and we take turns being lookouts.
I stand up tall on my back legs to watch for danger, like a little sentinel!
88: I'm a small wild animal from the Sahara Desert.
I'm nocturnal and I have an amazing sense of hearing.
I have the biggest ears of any fox -- they help me stay cool in the heat!
89: I'm a large animal from the cold, snowy north.
I travel in huge herds across the tundra.
I have big antlers and I'm famous for pulling a certain jolly man's sleigh!
90: I'm a strong, energetic dog breed from cold places.
I have thick fur and I love to run.
I pull sleds across the snow and I have striking blue eyes!
91: I'm a tiny rodent from the Arctic tundra.
I live under the snow and dig tunnels to find food.
People tell a myth that I run off cliffs, but that's not actually true!
92: I'm a small mammal from the Americas.
I have a very special kind of body armor.
I'm covered in hard, bony plates and I curl into a ball for protection!
93: I'm a fast bird that prefers running to flying.
I live in the deserts of the southwestern United States.
I can run up to 20 miles per hour and I say 'beep beep' in cartoons!
94: I'm a large bird of prey that soars high in the sky.
I have a bald head and a very keen sense of smell.
I circle in the sky looking for dead animals to eat -- I'm nature's cleanup crew!
95: I'm a wild animal related to wolves and dogs.
I live in North America and I'm very adaptable.
I howl at the moon at night and I'm known for being crafty and clever!
96: I'm a large reptile that loves warm, tropical climates.
I can often be seen basking in the sun on rocks or tree branches.
I'm green, I have a row of spines along my back, and a long, whip-like tail!
97: I'm a wild animal from Africa that hunts in packs.
I have one of the strongest bites of any mammal.
I look like a dog but I'm not one, and my laugh-like call is famous!
98: I'm a slow-moving reptile with a heavy shell.
I live on land and I can live for a very, very long time.
Some of my relatives have lived for over 150 years -- I'm one of the oldest animals on Earth!
99: I'm a hoofed animal from the grasslands of North America.
I'm the fastest land animal on my continent.
I can run nearly 60 miles per hour and I have two branching horns!
100: I'm a tiny rodent from the deserts of Asia and Africa.
I have very long back legs compared to my small body.
I hop like a tiny kangaroo and I have a super long tufted tail!
101: I'm a very unusual amphibian from Mexico.
I live in water my whole life and I never fully grow up.
I have feathery gills on my head and I can regrow lost body parts!
102: I'm one of the most hunted animals in the world.
I'm covered from head to tail in protective armor.
I have overlapping scales made of keratin and I curl into a tight ball when scared!
103: I'm a small, adorable mammal from the mountains of Asia.
I'm not actually closely related to giant pandas.
I have reddish-brown fur, a striped fluffy tail, and I look like a mix of a cat and a raccoon!
104: I'm a tree-dwelling marsupial from Australia.
I sleep up to 22 hours a day because my food gives me very little energy.
I eat eucalyptus leaves and I have a big round nose and fluffy ears!
105: I'm one of the strangest mammals on the planet.
I lay eggs even though I'm a mammal, and I have a bill like a duck.
I have a beaver-like tail, webbed feet, and the males have venomous spurs on their ankles!
106: I'm a big cat that lives high up in the mountains of Central Asia.
I have a very long, thick tail that I wrap around myself like a scarf.
I have beautiful spotted grey fur and I'm called the 'ghost of the mountains'!
107: I'm an unusual mammal from the rainforests of Central Africa.
I look like a mix of different animals and I was unknown to scientists until 1901.
I have a brown body with striped legs like a zebra, but I'm actually related to the giraffe!
108: I'm a small marsupial from a tiny island near Australia.
I'm known for my friendly, cheerful expression.
I always look like I'm smiling and I've been called 'the happiest animal on Earth'!
109: I'm a large, flightless bird from Australia and New Guinea.
I have a tall, bony crest on top of my head.
I have bright blue skin on my neck, I can be dangerous, and I'm considered one of the most dangerous birds alive!
110: I'm a strange nocturnal primate from Madagascar.
I have huge eyes, big ears, and bushy tail.
I tap on trees with my extra-long, bony middle finger to find insects hiding inside!
111: I'm a very rare, flightless bird from New Zealand.
I'm nocturnal and I'm the heaviest parrot in the world.
I'm a big, green, chubby parrot that can't fly, and there are fewer than 250 of me left!
112: I'm one of the rarest animals in the entire world.
I'm a small marine mammal that lives in one tiny part of one ocean.
I'm the world's smallest porpoise, found only in the Gulf of California, and I'm critically endangered!
113: I'm the largest rodent in the world.
I'm a very social and calm animal from South America.
I look like a giant guinea pig, I love water, and I'm friends with almost every other animal!
114: I'm a small marsupial from Australia.
I have a long, pointy snout and a striped back.
I use my long, sticky tongue to eat up to 20,000 termites every day!
115: I'm the top predator on the island of Madagascar.
I'm related to the mongoose but I look a bit like a small cougar.
I have a long tail, retractable claws, and I'm the only animal that hunts lemurs!
116: I'm a large reptile that lives in rivers in Asia.
I'm a type of crocodilian with a very unusual snout.
I have an extremely long, thin snout that's perfect for catching fish!
117: I'm one of the rarest mammals on the planet.
I was only discovered by scientists in 1992 in Southeast Asia.
I'm called the 'Asian unicorn' because I'm so rarely seen in the forests of Vietnam and Laos!
118: I'm a gentle marine mammal that lives in warm coastal waters.
I'm related to manatees and, strangely, to elephants.
I graze on seagrass and I'm sometimes called a 'sea cow'!
119: I'm a medium-sized wild cat from the forests of Southeast Asia.
I spend a lot of time in trees and I'm an excellent climber.
I have large, cloud-shaped blotches on my fur and the longest canine teeth relative to body size of any cat!
120: I'm one of the rarest primates in the world.
I live only on one island in China.
I'm a small ape from Hainan Island with fewer than 40 of us left, making me the rarest ape on Earth!

1: Dogs can understand up to 250 words and gestures, and they can count up to five!
A dog's nose print is unique, just like a human fingerprint -- no two are alike!
2: Cats spend about 70% of their lives sleeping -- that's around 16 hours a day!
A group of cats is called a 'clowder,' and cats can rotate their ears 180 degrees!
3: Chickens can remember over 100 different faces of people and other chickens!
Mother hens talk to their chicks while they are still inside the egg, and the chicks chirp back!
4: Cows have best friends and get stressed when they are separated from them!
A cow can walk upstairs but not downstairs because their knees can't bend the right way!
5: Sheep can recognize up to 50 other sheep faces and even 10 human faces for years!
Sheep have excellent memories and can remember events and faces for up to two years!
6: Pigs are smarter than dogs and can even learn to play video games with joysticks!
Pigs can't look up at the sky while standing -- their necks just won't let them!
7: Horses can sleep both lying down and standing up!
A horse can run within hours of being born, and they can see nearly 360 degrees around them!
8: Goats have rectangular pupils that give them a nearly 340-degree field of vision!
Goats were one of the first animals to be tamed by humans over 10,000 years ago!
9: Donkeys have an incredible memory and can remember places and other donkeys they've met 25 years ago!
A donkey's ears can be over 12 inches long, and they can hear another donkey calling from 60 miles away in the desert!
10: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 miles per hour, even though they look clumsy on the ground!
Benjamin Franklin wanted the turkey, not the bald eagle, to be the national bird of the United States!
11: Rabbits can't vomit, so they have to be very careful about what they eat!
A happy rabbit will jump and twist in the air -- this joyful move is called a 'binky'!
12: Ducks have waterproof feathers thanks to a special oil they spread with their beaks!
A duck's quack doesn't echo, and no one has been able to figure out exactly why!
13: Geese fly in a V-formation because it saves energy -- the birds in back ride the air current created by the ones in front!
Geese mate for life and will mourn when their partner dies, sometimes refusing to eat!
14: Llamas are used as guard animals to protect sheep and goats from coyotes and other predators!
Llamas hum to communicate with each other, and mothers hum to their babies!
15: Alpaca fiber is warmer than sheep's wool and is naturally water-resistant!
Alpacas use a communal dung pile -- the whole herd goes to the same spot to keep their space clean!
16: Guinea pigs 'popcorn' -- they jump straight up in the air when they are really happy!
Guinea pigs are born with their eyes open, a full coat of fur, and they can even run right away!
17: Hamsters can run up to 8 miles on their exercise wheel in a single night!
A hamster's cheek pouches extend all the way back to their shoulders and can hold a lot of food!
18: Goldfish have a memory span of at least three months, not just a few seconds like the myth says!
Goldfish can see more colors than humans can -- they can see ultraviolet and infrared light!
19: Parakeets can learn to say hundreds of words and even learn to count!
In the wild, parakeets live in huge flocks of thousands, chattering to each other constantly!
20: Some turtles can breathe through their rear end -- it helps them stay underwater longer!
Turtles have been on Earth for over 200 million years -- they were around when dinosaurs roamed!
21: Squirrels plant thousands of trees every year because they forget where they buried their acorns!
A squirrel's front teeth never stop growing, so they have to keep gnawing to keep them short!
22: Robins can see earthworms underground by detecting tiny movements in the soil!
Baby robins eat about 14 feet of earthworms every single day while growing up!
23: Deer can jump up to 10 feet high and 30 feet far in a single leap!
A baby deer (called a fawn) has no scent for the first week of its life, which helps it hide from predators!
24: Foxes use the Earth's magnetic field to help them hunt -- they can sense which direction is north!
A fox's tail is called a 'brush,' and they use it as a warm blanket in cold weather!
25: Raccoons have incredibly sensitive hands that become even more sensitive when wet, which is why they 'wash' their food!
Raccoons can remember solutions to tasks for up to three years!
26: Hedgehogs are immune to many snake venoms and can eat venomous snakes without being harmed!
Baby hedgehogs are called 'hoglets,' and they are born with soft spines under their skin that harden after a few hours!
27: Some frogs can freeze solid in winter and then thaw and hop away in spring, completely fine!
A group of frogs is called an 'army,' and the golden poison frog has enough toxin to be dangerous to 10 grown men!
28: Butterflies taste with their feet! They have taste sensors on their legs to find the right plants!
Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from Canada to Mexico every year -- and they've never made the trip before!
29: A ladybug can eat up to 5,000 aphids in its lifetime, making it a gardener's best friend!
Ladybugs bleed from their knees when threatened -- the smelly yellow liquid scares predators away!
30: A honeybee visits between 50 and 1,000 flowers in one trip and can fly up to 6 miles!
Bees communicate by dancing! A 'waggle dance' tells other bees where to find the best flowers!
31: A garden snail can sleep for up to three years if the weather is too dry!
Snails have thousands of tiny teeth on a ribbon-like tongue called a radula -- some species have over 20,000 teeth!
32: Pigeons can find their way home from over 1,000 miles away -- that's why people used them to carry messages!
Pigeons can recognize all 26 letters of the English alphabet and can even tell the difference between two different human beings in a photograph!
33: Sparrows have been living alongside humans for about 10,000 years -- as long as we've been farming!
A sparrow's heart beats over 800 times per minute, compared to a human's average of 72!
34: Bats are the only mammals that can truly fly -- other 'flying' mammals just glide!
A single brown bat can eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes in just one hour!
35: A mouse's heart beats about 632 times per minute -- almost 10 times faster than a human heart!
Mice sing ultrasonic love songs to each other that are too high-pitched for humans to hear!
36: A mole can dig a tunnel 300 feet long in just one night!
Moles have a special protein in their blood that lets them breathe recycled air in their underground tunnels!
37: Dragonflies have been on Earth for over 300 million years -- they existed before dinosaurs!
A dragonfly can fly in any direction, including backwards and sideways, and can hover in one spot like a helicopter!
38: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can stretch to three times the size of their head!
A chipmunk can gather up to 165 acorns in a single day!
39: An owl can rotate its head up to 270 degrees -- that's three-quarters of the way around!
Owls can't move their eyeballs at all, which is why they need to turn their whole head to look around!
40: Woodpeckers peck at trees up to 20 times per second, and their brains are specially cushioned to prevent damage!
A woodpecker's tongue can be up to 4 inches long and wraps around the inside of its skull when not in use!
41: Dolphins sleep with one eye open! Only half their brain sleeps at a time so they can keep breathing!
Every dolphin has a unique whistle that acts like a name -- other dolphins use it to call them!
42: A blue whale's heart is so big that a small child could crawl through its arteries!
Blue whale babies gain about 200 pounds every single day during their first year of life!
43: Sharks have been around for over 400 million years -- they're older than trees!
Sharks can sense a single drop of blood in an Olympic-sized swimming pool!
44: An octopus has three hearts and blue blood!
Octopuses have been seen using coconut shells as portable shelters -- they carry them around and hide inside!
45: Male seahorses are the ones who get pregnant and give birth to the babies -- the only males in the animal kingdom that do!
Seahorses don't have stomachs, so food passes through them very quickly and they need to eat almost constantly!
46: Some jellyfish are immortal! The Turritopsis jellyfish can revert back to its baby form and start its life cycle over!
Jellyfish are about 95% water and have no brain, no blood, and no heart!
47: Sea turtles have been around since the time of the dinosaurs, over 110 million years ago!
Sea turtles can hold their breath for up to 5 hours by slowing their heart rate to conserve oxygen!
48: All clownfish are born male, and the dominant one in a group can change into a female!
Clownfish have a special slimy mucus coating that protects them from the anemone's stinging tentacles!
49: Starfish don't have blood -- instead, they pump seawater through their bodies!
A starfish can regrow an entire new arm, and sometimes a single arm can grow a whole new starfish!
50: Crabs walk sideways because of the way their leg joints bend -- it's actually faster for them!
The Japanese spider crab has legs that can span up to 12 feet from tip to tip -- that's bigger than a car!
51: Lobsters taste with their feet and chew with their stomachs!
Lobsters can live for over 100 years, and they keep growing their entire lives -- they never stop!
52: Seals can sleep underwater and come up to breathe automatically without waking up!
A seal's whiskers are so sensitive they can detect fish swimming nearby, even in complete darkness!
53: A walrus can eat up to 4,000 clams in one feeding session!
Walruses use their tusks like ice picks to pull their heavy bodies out of the water onto ice!
54: Emperor penguins can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet and hold their breath for more than 20 minutes!
Penguin dads keep their eggs warm by balancing them on their feet under a flap of skin for two months without eating!
55: Pufferfish contain a toxin called tetrodotoxin that is up to 1,200 times more poisonous than cyanide!
Despite being so toxic, pufferfish is considered a delicacy in Japan, but chefs must train for years to prepare it safely!
56: Manta rays have the largest brains of any fish and can recognize themselves in mirrors!
Manta rays can have a wingspan of up to 23 feet -- that's wider than many cars are long!
57: Electric eels can generate up to 860 volts of electricity -- enough to stun a horse!
Eels can swim both forwards and backwards, and some species travel thousands of miles to lay their eggs!
58: Giant squid have the largest eyes in the animal kingdom -- each one can be as big as a dinner plate!
Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body!
59: Orcas are actually the largest member of the dolphin family, not whales!
Different orca groups speak different 'dialects' -- each pod has its own unique set of calls!
60: A narwhal's tusk is actually a giant tooth that grows in a spiral and can be up to 10 feet long!
Narwhal tusks have millions of nerve endings, and scientists think they use them to sense changes in the water!
61: A lion's roar can be heard from up to 5 miles away -- it's the loudest of any big cat!
Lions sleep up to 20 hours a day, and it's actually the female lions that do most of the hunting!
62: Every tiger has a unique pattern of stripes, just like human fingerprints -- no two tigers are alike!
Tigers are one of the few big cats that actually enjoy swimming and playing in water!
63: Elephants are the only animals that can't jump, but they can communicate using vibrations felt through their feet!
An elephant's trunk has over 40,000 muscles and can pick up something as small as a single grain of rice!
64: A giraffe's tongue can be up to 20 inches long and is dark purple to protect it from sunburn!
Giraffes only need about 30 minutes of sleep per day -- one of the shortest sleep requirements of any animal!
65: Capuchin monkeys have been observed using rocks as tools to crack open nuts for at least 3,000 years!
Spider monkeys can swing through trees at speeds of up to 35 miles per hour using just their arms and tail!
66: Gorillas share about 98% of their DNA with humans, making them one of our closest relatives!
Gorillas can learn sign language -- a gorilla named Koko learned over 1,000 signs and understood about 2,000 words of English!
67: African grey parrots are considered one of the smartest birds -- they can learn over 1,000 words and use them in context!
Parrots are one of the few animals that can truly learn to say new sounds by imitating them, just like humans!
68: A toucan's beak is made of keratin (the same stuff as your fingernails) and has air pockets inside that make it surprisingly lightweight!
Toucans regulate their body temperature through their beaks -- blood flow to the beak releases heat like a radiator!
69: Jaguars have the strongest bite of any big cat -- they can bite right through a turtle's shell!
Unlike most cats, jaguars love water and are excellent swimmers who hunt caimans and fish in rivers!
70: Snakes smell with their tongues! They flick their forked tongue to collect scent particles from the air!
Some snakes can go up to two years without eating a single meal!
71: Crocodiles have been around for about 200 million years and lived alongside dinosaurs!
Crocodiles can't stick their tongues out! Their tongues are attached to the roof of their mouths!
72: Hippos produce a natural red-pink 'sunscreen' from their skin that protects them from the sun!
Despite their round shape, hippos can run up to 19 miles per hour on land -- faster than most humans!
73: A rhinoceros horn is made entirely of keratin -- the same protein found in your hair and fingernails!
Despite their poor eyesight, rhinos have amazing hearing and can rotate their ears in all directions to pick up sounds!
74: Every zebra has a unique stripe pattern, like a fingerprint -- no two zebras are exactly alike!
Scientists believe zebra stripes may help confuse biting flies and keep the zebras cooler in hot weather!
75: A chameleon's tongue can shoot out faster than a jet fighter plane takes off -- in just 1/100th of a second!
Chameleons don't actually change color to match their background -- they change color based on their mood, temperature, and light!
76: Sloths are such slow movers that algae grows on their fur, giving them a greenish tint that helps them hide in trees!
Sloths only come down from their trees about once a week to go to the bathroom!
77: Orangutans are the largest tree-dwelling animals on Earth and spend about 90% of their time up in trees!
Orangutans make umbrellas out of large leaves when it rains -- they're one of the few animals to use tools from nature!
78: Black panthers aren't a separate species -- they're leopards or jaguars with extra melanin that makes their fur look black!
If you look closely at a black panther in sunlight, you can still see their spots hidden in the dark fur!
79: Flamingos are born white or grey -- they turn pink because of pigments in the shrimp and algae they eat!
Flamingos can only eat with their heads upside down, and they stomp their feet to stir up food from the mud!
80: A peacock's tail feathers can be over 5 feet long -- more than 60% of the bird's total body length!
The colorful 'eyes' on a peacock's feathers aren't paint or pigment -- they're created by tiny crystal structures that reflect light!
81: Polar bears have black skin under their white fur to absorb heat from the sun!
A polar bear can smell a seal from over 20 miles away and through 3 feet of ice!
82: Arctic foxes can survive temperatures as low as minus 58 degrees Fahrenheit thanks to their thick fur!
An Arctic fox's fluffy tail is so warm that they wrap it around themselves like a blanket when sleeping!
83: Snowy owls can eat up to 1,600 lemmings in a single year -- that's about 3 to 5 per day!
Unlike most owls that are nocturnal, snowy owls are active during the day because in the Arctic, summer days have 24 hours of sunlight!
84: Camels can drink up to 40 gallons of water in one go -- that's enough to fill a bathtub!
A camel's hump stores fat, not water! The fat provides energy when food is scarce in the desert!
85: Scorpions glow bright blue-green under ultraviolet light, and scientists still aren't completely sure why!
Some scorpion species can survive for an entire year without eating any food at all!
86: A rattlesnake adds a new segment to its rattle every time it sheds its skin!
Rattlesnakes can sense body heat using special pits on their face, allowing them to 'see' warm-blooded animals in complete darkness!
87: Meerkats take turns standing guard while the rest of the group looks for food -- they even have different alarm calls for different predators!
Baby meerkats are taught how to handle scorpions by adult meerkats who remove the stinger first!
88: Fennec foxes have ears that can be 6 inches long -- the largest ears relative to body size of any carnivore!
The soles of a fennec fox's feet are covered in thick fur that acts like snowshoes on the hot desert sand!
89: Reindeer are the only deer species where both males and females grow antlers!
Reindeer eyes change color from gold in summer to blue in winter to help them see better in low Arctic light!
90: Huskies have a special double coat that keeps them warm at minus 60 degrees and cool in summer!
Huskies have been helping people in the Arctic for over 3,000 years, and they can run over 100 miles in a day!
91: Lemmings don't actually run off cliffs on purpose -- that's a myth made famous by a 1958 documentary that staged the scene!
Lemmings are excellent swimmers and can cross rivers and small lakes during their mass migrations!
92: The nine-banded armadillo always gives birth to identical quadruplets -- four babies that are all exactly the same!
Armadillos can hold their breath for up to six minutes, and they can walk along the bottom of streams underwater!
93: Roadrunners can run up to 20 miles per hour, making them one of the fastest running birds!
Roadrunners eat rattlesnakes! They grab the snake by the tail and smack its head on the ground!
94: Vultures have extremely strong stomach acid that can destroy dangerous bacteria, allowing them to eat rotten meat safely!
Some vultures pee on their own legs to cool down -- the evaporation helps lower their body temperature!
95: Coyotes can run at speeds of up to 43 miles per hour and can jump over 13-foot fences!
Coyotes have adapted to live in every habitat in North America, from deserts to forests and even big cities!
96: Green iguanas have a special 'third eye' on top of their head that can sense light and shadows above them!
Iguanas can fall from 50 feet up in a tree, hit the ground, and walk away without getting hurt!
97: Hyenas have one of the most powerful bites in the animal kingdom -- strong enough to crush bones!
Hyenas are actually more closely related to cats than dogs, even though they look like dogs!
98: The oldest known tortoise ever recorded lived to be 190 years old!
A tortoise's shell is actually part of its skeleton -- it's made up of about 60 bones fused together!
99: Pronghorns are the fastest land animals in North America and can sustain speeds of 55 mph for miles!
Pronghorns evolved their speed to outrun the now-extinct American cheetah!
100: Jerboas can jump up to 10 feet in a single leap -- that's over 10 times their body length!
Jerboas get all the water they need from the seeds they eat -- they never need to drink water!
101: Axolotls can regrow entire limbs, parts of their brain, heart, and other organs!
Axolotls are called 'Peter Pan salamanders' because they never go through metamorphosis -- they keep their baby features their whole lives!
102: Pangolins are the only mammals in the world covered in scales!
When curled into a ball, a pangolin's scales are so tough that even lions can't bite through them!
103: Red pandas were discovered about 50 years before giant pandas, so they were actually the original 'panda'!
Red pandas use their bushy, ringed tails as blankets to keep warm while they sleep in cold mountain forests!
104: Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day because eucalyptus leaves are so low in nutrition and hard to digest!
Baby koalas (called joeys) are born the size of a jellybean and crawl into their mother's pouch to continue growing!
105: When the platypus was first sent to scientists in England, they thought it was a prank -- someone had sewn a duck's bill onto a beaver!
Platypuses can detect the electric fields generated by other animals' muscles, helping them find prey underwater with their eyes closed!
106: Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound -- that's the length of a school bus!
Snow leopards can't roar like other big cats! Instead, they make a friendly puffing sound called a 'chuff'!
107: Okapis were unknown to Western science until 1901, making them one of the last large mammals to be discovered!
Okapis have tongues so long (about 18 inches) that they can lick their own ears and eyelids clean!
108: Quokkas are known as 'the happiest animal on Earth' because of the natural smile on their face!
Quokkas can survive for long periods without food or water by living off the fat stored in their tails!
109: Cassowaries are considered one of the most dangerous birds in the world -- they have a dagger-like claw on each foot!
Cassowary dads are single fathers -- the male incubates the eggs and raises the chicks entirely on his own!
110: The aye-aye has an extra-long, skeletal middle finger that it uses to tap on trees and fish out insect larvae!
Aye-ayes are the world's largest nocturnal primate, and they are the only primates that use echolocation-like tapping to find food!
111: The kakapo is the only flightless parrot in the world and can live for over 90 years!
Male kakapos attract mates by making a deep booming sound that can be heard up to 3 miles away!
112: The vaquita is the most endangered marine mammal in the world, with fewer than 10 individuals believed to remain!
Vaquitas were not even discovered by scientists until 1958, and they have been in danger ever since!
113: Capybaras are so friendly and calm that other animals like birds, monkeys, and even crocodiles hang out on or near them!
Capybaras are excellent swimmers and can hold their breath underwater for up to five minutes!
114: Numbats are one of the few marsupials that are active during the day instead of at night!
A numbat's tongue can be up to 4 inches long and can flick in and out of a termite mound up to 100 times per minute!
115: The fossa is the largest predator on Madagascar and is the only animal that regularly hunts lemurs!
Fossas can climb down trees headfirst thanks to their flexible ankles that can rotate nearly 180 degrees!
116: Gharials have over 100 razor-sharp teeth, all perfectly designed for catching slippery fish!
Male gharials develop a bulbous growth on their snout called a 'ghara' that they use to make buzzing sounds and blow bubbles to attract mates!
117: The saola is so rare that it has been spotted in the wild only a handful of times since its discovery in 1992!
The saola is sometimes called the 'Asian unicorn' -- not because it has one horn, but because it is so incredibly hard to find!
118: Dugongs are the only marine mammals that are strictly herbivorous -- they eat nothing but seagrass!
Dugongs are closely related to elephants, and they can live for up to 70 years!
119: Clouded leopards have the longest canine teeth relative to body size of any living cat -- they're sometimes called 'modern-day saber-tooths'!
Clouded leopards can hang upside down from branches using just their hind feet and climb down trees headfirst!
120: The Hainan gibbon is the rarest ape on Earth, with only about 35 to 40 individuals left in the wild!
Hainan gibbons can swing through the treetops at speeds of up to 35 miles per hour, covering gaps of over 30 feet in a single leap!
